name: Assassin’s Creed® Chronicles: China
description: The first entry in the Assassin’s Creed Chronicles saga takes place in China, 1526, as the Ming dynasty starts to crumble. You embody Shao Jun, the last remaining Assassin of the Chinese Brotherhood, returning to her homeland with a vendetta.

reviews.review_text: I couldn't believe it when I heard Shao Jun would be returning. Ever since Assassin's Creed Embers I've wanted to see her back but didn't expect much from Ubisoft. While I was slightly disappointed that they didn't make a typical AC game out of her story, I'm happy to see how this turned out. I really dig the art style which adds perfectly to the overall ambience of the game and it actually creates more of the original AC feeling than especially Unity failed to.  One point for this is that AC China rewards you for being sneaky. You get a much higher rating if you stealth your way through a level and kill no one. Also, the combat is challenging, or has been at least for me. One enemy, mabye two, totally fine to take on, but anything above three seems more like suicide.  The soundtrack isn't overdoing it, especially in the action sequences, and there are subtle notes woven in that must be from Jesper Kyd's ACII OST, and now, guess what, I wanna replay that game.  It took me about 11 hours to finish because I wanted nothing as bad as not being seen and I applaud myself for managing that (in most levels).   Do yourself a favor and buy this game, buy it once, buy it five times so you can give it to your friends which is a much better investment than buying Unity.

There is an echo of Enter the Ninja, but this game is way more than just a knock off. There is a learning curve to sword combat, guards will use throwing stars, some guards have a crossbow you have to dodge. I've only played the first two levels and they are huge and beautifully drawn. Don't be put off by the 2.5, it's very well done. And it is nice to finally play in an Asian setting, especially with a female protagonist.

Starting out from the main franchaise and branching into these 'mini' games, Ubi is taking the term 'assassin' to serious lengths. The Chronicles really reward you for stealth and speed as well as patience and is a true mark of the stealth brand.   It took some time to get used to it and it took me months to get back to it because, admittedly it is not for everyone of this generation which is used to the high res games that have the option of murdering your way through levels. But after a while, i got the hang of the 2D dimensions and the controls are now able to be readjusted (thank god). It is extremely satisfying to get Shadow Gold on a checkpoint - which is when you are not seen and don't kill anyone except targets  But wait? Don't kill anyone? Aren't we supposed to slish slash through blood in an AC game? But wait! Aren't we supposed to be Assassins? Working in the dark? It makes logical sense, and yes it adds a layer of difficulty to it, but overall i really enjoyed this game and am playing through it again at the harder difficulties to get teh achievements and collectibles.  The controls are clunky but now that you can adjust it, its actually makes you have really good coordination of control. I liked this game.
great value for ten dollars, a satisfying 2.5d stealth game. Maintains some of the flow of the 3d installments in the series.

This is more of a mobile game ported to the PC kinda game. Really short and not too much to do in it really. For once, this game has nothing about the assassins VS templars in modern times like in the previous games and you could say it is just another Assassins story. This time the main character is a girl from China who was trained by Master Assassin himself, Ezio Auditore (the main character of Assassin's Creed 2). The game can be finished in less than 5 hours or even less as I was doing some of the challenges you can get in each section like not being detected or find some item, which can extend some time into the sections of the game.   Usually the Stealth option will be better as the combat it is not really good, you will good if you manage to avoid the combat in this game, of course there are some parts where you don't have a choice but there are not too many in the game.  Graphic and sound wise the game is very average and themed to the main character; nothing really innovative, just average or what you will expect from it.  If you want to try a different Assassin's Creed, this game could be good for you, but be aware it is really short.

First off, don't come in expecting nearly the kind of experience a main AC game would give you. This is a 2.5d platformer. That said, it's not a bad one, but it's also not the best one ever. This is honestly a rather average game as far as the genre comes. You've got a few interesting moves, but nothing you might not expect. It introduces the shoe blade, but honestly, it's just a different animation.   Ubisoft, if you're reading this, stop teasing us. Being an assassin is a lot like what you'd expect out of being a ninja. Stop mulling about and let us be ninjas. Do a main game in an Asian environment. Be it China, Japan, Korea, what-have-you. I'm pretty sure I'm not the only one that would pay for that.  Bottom line, this is not a bad game. The main reason I'm not reccommending it is because A) I expected the type of gameplay I got in other AC games, and was denied, and B) I'm not sure how many people would pay full price for it if it weren't AC.

I'm a sucker for AC, and I often find myself playing the games and aiming for 100% completion despite their flaws.   I was interested when I first heard about this smaller digital games. As a child I remember the magic of playing Prince of Persia with it's precision timing, jumps, and sword fighting. I figured if the game could simply live up to the standard sset by that 30 year old game, then what could go wrong.  And that is the problem with the game. It technically doesn't do anything wrong.... but it doesn't really do anything right either. So I'm having a difficult time deciding whether or not I can reommned the game.   I'll start with comparisons to Prince of Persia (I'm talking the old DOS game here, not the PS2/Xbox era game). While AC Chronicles China is not as unforgiving as PoP, it is also not as accurate. Similar to it's 3D big brothers, your assasin has a bad habit of going in directions you didn't intend. This can lead to countless 'restart checkpoints' if you are aiming for higher scores. The running, jumping, sliding, and other movment mechanics are pretty good. My favorite levels often invovled skill runs through a collapsing environment. On the othe rhand, the combat sections are simply not fun, and I think the developers knew that, which is why you are punished very heavily score-wise for getting invovled in sword combat. Considering charatcer upgrades are tied to your level scores, this means you are heavily pushed towards silently moving through levels unseen. And if you have to kill, don't be seen while doing it.   Which leads me to wonder why the bothered with so many combat mechanics. Blocking, countering, rolling over enemines, light attacks, heavy attacks, are all mechanics that, if you play as the game encourgaes you to, will never actually be used. It reminded me of the older splinter cell games that gave you 20 gadgets to kill a man, and then penalized you for killing.  The story itself is fairly shallow. Precursor artifact? check. Crumbling assasin brotherhood? check. Gang of evil templars in a convient order of importance? check. Assassin that doesn't listen to their master and causes trouble? check. This is all familar territory. and it really only serves to set up the flimsiest of reasons as to why we are killing all these guys.   As this is the first game in a 3 part series, it is hard to tell at this point how much lore the series will ultimately add to the AC universe. At this point it very well could be a throwaway story, or the precursor artiofact mentioned might end up being something rather important.  That is honestly where the developers should be focused at this point. The AC universe is dense and can be somewhat convoluted. There are fans who understand everything about the lore and many more who know there are artifacts and ancioents, but aren't really clear on what their deal is. Smaller games like this are the perfect opportunity to flesh these things out. Define the artifacts. Define the background stories of people who have met or heard about.   So far, these games don't feel like they are going that route. Rather they had a list of lcoations from a brain storm meeting on where the next big AC game should be, and someone took the scraps that got lef ton the table and decided to make this series based on them.  Ultimately, the gameplay is serviceable and I had moments where I felt pretty badass. Sliding from hiding spot to hiding spot with only split seconds to spare is pretty awesome. That is until you go to jump into the next spot and your assassin instead decides to jump on a guards head and then just stare at him while every enemy in the area lights you up. If the game had a better story, then based on the gameplay as it stands, I would have gone ahead and given a thumbs up. Unfortunately the game could literally have been called anything, because other than name dropping Ezio and mentions of the artifact, there is nothing else Assassin's Creed about the game. And for that reason, I can't recommend it. There are better action platformers out there. And there are enough other AC games that have more variety, better gameplay, and more substance that are worth your time and money.

Let's start with: I have played this for longer than Steam seems to think I have.  I really like playing this game. There's something about the AC series that translated really well to 2.5D. I'd long since abandoned the franchise (way back when they released 5001 add-ons to Ezio's story) and this was a welcome re-entry for me.  Running through the beautifully-designed and vibrant levels honestly makes me smile. The bright red blood spatters when Shao drives her 'Toe-blade' into a Templar's skull is a really satisfying feeling. It's quite the treasure of a game, and for the price of £7.99 (or your regional equivalent) it is well worth your time and money.  To view my full review, visit  my site. I actually liked this game, even though it commits the unforgiveable sin of not allowing players to assign their own keys (bind) to actions. Because the game looked worth playing, what I did was treat using the hardwired WASD keys for movement, C for action, etc. as something of a puzzle-within-the-puzzle game -- and it worked. Once I got the keys down, the game was actually a lot of fun. Stealthy, a generous checkpoint system, responsive, great-looking. While I still consider not allowing players to rebind their own keys a deal-killer in most cases, I'm glad I set it aside this time.
